title: How the Body Moves
description: Learn the fundamental movement types used in physiotherapy to describe how joints and body parts move.

words.fact: Flexion is a bending movement that decreases the angle at a joint. Why it matters: it enables actions like sitting or lifting. Today's takeaway: flexion helps the body fold and move inward.
Extension straightens a joint and increases the angle between bones. Why it matters: it supports standing and reaching. Today's takeaway: extension helps the body return to an upright position.
Rotation is a twisting movement around an axis. Why it matters: it allows turning motions of the neck and trunk. Today's takeaway: rotation enables controlled directional movement.
Pronation involves turning a limb so the palm or foot faces downward. Why it matters: it supports grip and walking mechanics. Today's takeaway: pronation helps absorb force during movement.
Lateral movement shifts the body or limb sideways. Why it matters: it improves balance and stability. Today's takeaway: lateral control supports safe and coordinated motion.
